name: Tommy Hilfiger
about: Tommy Hilfiger is a global fashion brand known for its classic American style with a modern twist. Founded in 1985, the brand offers apparel, accessories, and footwear for men, women, and children.
In 2016, Tommy Adaptive launched. Collection aims to make fashion more inclusive for people with disabilities by modifying classic Tommy styles.

features.label: Magnetic Buttons
features.text: Easy fastening alternatives for those with dexterity limitations

features.label: Comfort Construction
features.text: No uncomfortable seams, pockets, or tags

features.label: Multiple Openings
features.text: Front, side, and back openings for easy dressing

name: No Limbits
about: Founded in 2019, No Limbits is a disability owned adaptive clothing brand founded by Erica Cole, an engineer and amputee. The company designs modern, functional, and affordable clothing for amputees, wheelchair users, and individuals with sensory sensitivities.
Adaptive clothing lines based on customer’s specific needs rather than their general disability category. Lines include unlimbed, wheelchair, sensory, and limited dexterity.

features.label: Adjustable Fit
features.text: Waistbands and hems for custom comfort

features.label: Prosthetic-friendly Openings
features.text: Side zippers for casts and braces

features.label: No Harsh Construction
features.text: No uncomfortable seams, pockets, or tags

name: Joe & Bella
about: Joe & Bella is a “passion project” that came from the personal experiences of caring and advocating for degrading mobility in aging parents. Though their clothing line is intended to bring a sense of autonomy and dignity for older adults, their adaptive clothing can aid a wide range of women and men who have mobility obstacles.
Designed for older adults and people with limited mobility. Focuses on easy dressing and undressing. Reduces the need for excessive struggles and physical assistance.

features.label: Open-Back Clothing
features.text: Ideal for caregivers and limited mobility

features.label: Discreet Adaptive Designs
features.text: Maintains normal appearance but more functional

name: MagnaReady
about: MagnaReady was created on the basis of restoring freedom in the daily routine of getting dressed and undressed. The company was founded after the personal experience of caregiving for a spouse with Parkinson’s disease.
They pioneered magnetic shirt closures and offer functional and stylish clothing options for men and women.

features.label: Magnetic Shirts
features.text: Wide range of adaptive tops and jackets

name: Seven7 Adaptive Line
about: Seven7 Jeans introduced their adaptive line to offer stylish, functional denim and casual wear to people living with disabilities.
They emphasize accessibility without compromising style and aim to serve a broad range of individuals.

name: Zappos Adaptive
about: Zappos Adaptive was created to provide convenient and fashionable clothing options for people with disabilities or sensitivities.
Products available for elderly, kids, and adults across clothing and footwear.

features.label: Medical Fit Footwear
features.text: Extra depth and width for swelling

name: Adidas
about: Adidas started a line of clothing designed to better fit seated athletes. Their line came out in 2024 and is used for National Wheelchair Basketball uniforms.

name: Friendly Shoes
about: Started by an occupational therapist. Designed for easy slip-on shoes with zipper access for low dexterity users.

features.label: Adaptive Zippers
features.text: Helps slip on shoes while appearing standard

name: Nike
about: Nike introduced FlyEase technology in 2015 after a letter from a teen with cerebral palsy.
Designed for broad disability accessibility with easy-entry shoes.

name: JCPenney - Jamey Perry
about: JCPenney introduced the Jamey Perry line in 2021 for wheelchair users and people with disabilities.

name: Buck & Buck
about: Buck & Buck specializes in adaptive underwear and clothing for people with limited mobility and incontinence needs.

name: VANS
notes: Brand discontinued — kept for historical reference
about: VANS partnered with A.skate Foundation and IBCCES to create sensory-friendly shoes for children with Autism.
